message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest acute myeloid leukemia (AML). The presence of Auer Rods in the peripheral blood smear and >30% blast cells in the bone marrow confirm the diagnosis. Among the options, only t(15;17) is associated with AML, specifically the variant called acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest acute myeloid leukemia (AML). The Auer rods and >30% blast cells on bone marrow biopsy confirm this diagnosis. The t(15;17) translocation is associated with the subtype of AML known as acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), which is characterized by bleeding and coagulation abnormalities, such as the patient’s prolonged bleeding time and petechiae. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) t(15;17).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML), which correlates with the blast cells seen in bone marrow biopsy. The gum hypertrophy and oral mucosal petechiae suggest gingival hyperplasia, which is a feature of AML M3 subtype associated with t(15;17) chromosomal translocation. JAK2 mutation is associated with Myeloproliferative neoplasms, t(9;22) with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia, and t(11;14) with Mantle Cell Lymphoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest acute myeloid leukemia (AML), which is further confirmed by the peripheral blood smear and bone marrow biopsy. Among the options, only t(15;17) is associated with AML, specifically acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). JAK2 mutation is associated with myeloproliferative disorders, t(9;22) with chronic myeloid leukemia, and t(11;14) with mantle cell lymphoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with symptoms of leukemia, and the presence of Auer rods and myeloperoxidase-positive cells in the peripheral blood smear and bone marrow biopsy confirm the diagnosis. The associated chromosomal abnormality with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), the most likely diagnosis based on the symptoms and findings, is t(15;17). The other options are associated with different types of leukemia and blood disorders.

JAK2 mutation is associated with myeloproliferative disorders, t(9;22) with chronic myeloid leukemia, and t(11;14) with mantle cell lymphoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical findings of this patient suggest acute myeloid leukemia, specifically acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). The t(15;17) chromosomal translocation is a characteristic genetic abnormality seen in APL. The other options are associated with other types of leukemia and myeloproliferative disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), which is associated with t(15;17) chromosomal abnormality. JAK2 mutation is associated with myeloproliferative neoplasms, t(9;22) with chronic myeloid leukemia, and t(11;14) with mantle cell lymphoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, physical examination findings, and blood tests suggest acute myeloid leukemia (AML). The presence of Auer rods and >30% blast cells in bone marrow biopsy confirms the diagnosis. Among the options, only t(15;17) is associated with AML subtype M3 or acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL).

The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest acute leukemia, and the peripheral blood smear and bone marrow biopsy confirm the diagnosis. Among the options, only the t(15;17) chromosomal abnormality is associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia, which is characterized by gum hypertrophy and bleeding tendency.
